title-group.article-title: A review on plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for degradation of organic pollutants in wastewater

sec.p: Organic pollutants in wastewater are the biggest problem facing the world today due to population growth, rapid increase in industrialization, urbanization, and technological advancement. There have been numerous attempts to use conventional wastewater treatment techniques to address the issue of worldwide water contamination. However, conventional wastewater treatment has a number of shortcomings, including high operating costs, low efficiency, difficult preparation, fast recombination of charge carriers, generation of secondary waste, and limited light absorption. Therefore, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts have attracted much attention as a promising method to reduce organic pollutant problems in water due to their excellent efficiency, low operating cost, ease of fabrication, and environmental friendliness. In addition, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts contain a local surface plasmon resonance that enhances the performance of photocatalysts by improving light absorption and separation of photoexcited charge carriers. This review summarizes the major plasmonic effects in photocatalysts, including hot electron, local field effect, and photothermal effect, and explains the plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts with five junction systems for the degradation of pollutants. Recent work on the development of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the degradation of various organic pollutants in wastewater is also discussed. Lastly, the conclusions and challenges are briefly described and the direction of future development of heterojunction photocatalysts with plasmonic materials is explored. This review could serve as a guide for the understanding, investigation, and construction of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for various organic pollutants degradation.

sec.title: Graphical abstract
sec.p: Herein, the plasmonic effects in photocatalysts, such as hot electrons, local field effect, and photothermal effect, as well as the plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts with five junction systems for the degradation of pollutants are explained. Recent work on plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the degradation of various organic pollutants in wastewater such as dyes, pesticides, phenols, and antibiotics is discussed. Challenges and future developments are also described.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to the increase in world population and continuous industrial and agricultural development, an increasing trend in organic pollutants in water sources has been observed worldwide [1, 2]. Organic pollutants contained in wastewater have serious effects on the environment, human health, and consequently on the economy [3, 4]. Moreover, water is a valuable source that needs to be adequately treated, recycled, and conserved so that it can continue to be used in all aspects of life and to protect the environment from the serious effects of organic pollutants. However, it is necessary to develop wastewater treatment techniques to reuse wastewater and reduce pollution [5]. Therefore, various conventional methods such as flocculation, filtration, coagulation, reverse osmosis, sedimentation, adsorption, advanced oxidation, disinfection, and biological methods are used for wastewater treatment [6]. However, the effectiveness of these remediation methods is limited when it comes to removing persistent organic pollutants from wastewater. In addition, many conventional methods are inefficient, chemically expensive, and time-consuming, and most merely shift pollutants from one phase to another [7–9].

In recent decades, heterojunction photocatalysts have fascinated much attention and have appeared as a promising green and environmentally friendly method for removing organic pollutants in wastewater, as they can convert pollutants into harmless compounds with the help of abundant sunlight [10–12]. Much has been written in the literature about heterojunction photocatalysts for wastewater treatment because of their unique properties such as ease of fabrication, low cost, chemical stability, and non-toxicity [13–15]. However, heterojunction photocatalysts have some drawbacks that limit their practical application such as rapid recombination of charge carriers and limited absorption of visible light, which reduces the photocatalytic efficiency [16, 17]. Therefore, the photocatalytic efficiency of the heterojunction photocatalyst can be greatly improved by coating the photocatalyst surface with metal nanoparticles (NPs) as plasmonic materials known as plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts [18, 19]. The metal NPs as plasmonic materials have fundamentally increased the catalytic efficiency of heterojunction photocatalysts in this situation by serving as co-catalysts [20]. Moreover, the resulting metal NPs/heterojunction photocatalyst structure contributes to the improved greatly separation of photoexcited charge carriers and absorption of light owing to its localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) associated with collective oscillation of surface electrons [21, 22].

It is known that the development of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts is a successful strategy to promote the photoexcited electrons–holes (e−–h+) separation and improve light absorption [23]. Numerous studies have shown that LSPR in plasmonic materials can improve charge separation and light absorption, which significantly increases photocatalytic efficiency [24, 25]. Various physical, biological and chemical processes have been extensively used for the preparation of plasmonic photocatalysts [26, 27]. In 2008 [28], Awazu et al. introduced the term “plasmonic photocatalyst”. A flurry of studies into plasmonic photocatalysts was immediately generated by this work, which showed the usefulness of the LSPR for photocatalysts. The early research conducted by Kamat’s group [29, 30] and others [31, 32] used LSPR to improve photocatalyst performance. The LSPR in plasmonic metal NPs is beneficial for the performance of photocatalytic processes in many ways. For instance, it helps in generating hot charge carriers [33], enhancing the local electric field [34], and improving photothermal heating [35, 36]. These unique features of the plasmonic metal NPs have significantly improved the photocatalytic efficiency of heterojunction photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation.

Recently, researchers have prepared several heterojunction photocatalysts with different metal NPs for organic pollutants degradation. In addition, various modification methods for the plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalyst have been proposed by loading metal NPs as co-catalysts into the heterojunction photocatalysts [37, 38]. Thus, many reviews have encouraged the use of simple heterojunction photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation [39–41]. However, the rapid recombination of the photogenerated e−–h+ pairs and the limited light absorption currently limit the practical application of this heterojunction photocatalyst technique [16, 42]. An efficient way for heterojunction photocatalysts is to modify them with plasmonic metal NPs, as the LSPR can enhance the absorption in the ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) region and the excitation of active e−–h+, which can greatly improve the photocatalytic activity of the material in removing organic pollutants [43, 44]. Therefore, it is necessary to comprehensively investigate the photodegradation applications of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the treatment of organic pollutants from wastewater. In recent years, many review papers on photocatalysts with plasmonic materials have been published that summarized the preparation approaches, and their applications in environmental remediation [45–47]. However, in these review papers, limited attention is paid to plasmonic effects in photocatalysts. Moreover, the plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts with five junction systems and their related mechanism in photocatalysts are not reviewed. This review paper aims to provide valuable information on plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, including plasmonic effects in photocatalysts, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts with five junction systems, mechanism, and their application for the degradation of various organic pollutants in wastewater. It is expected that this perspective will provide researchers with some new insights, inspirations, and ideas to promote the fabrication of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants in wastewater.

This review paper discusses the elimination of various organic pollutants from wastewater by plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts. The main goal of this review is to evaluate current initiatives to develop plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, investigate the related mechanisms in photocatalysts, and improve the efficiency of photocatalysts for organic pollutant degradation. Conclusions and challenges are briefly described and the direction of future development of heterojunction photocatalysts with plasmonic materials is explored. We anticipate that this review will serve as a guide for researchers working in the related fields.

sec.title: Plasmonic effect for photocatalytic degradation
sec.p: The incorporation of metal NPs into the heterojunction photocatalysts can further improve the photocatalytic behavior to some extent through the plasmonic effect. This is due to LSPR enhanced charge separation ratio and significant visible light absorption [48, 49]. Plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are an efficient way to improve photocatalytic performance in removing organic pollutants by mixing heterojunction photocatalysts with a precise amount of metal NPs [50, 51]. In plasmonic photocatalysts, the interaction between metal NPs and semiconductors causes substantial changes in a variety of photocatalysts. The most noticeable characteristic of plasmonic photocatalysts is the LSPR of the metal NPs in light, which intensifies the hot electron excitation, local field, and photothermal effect. Thus, hot electron generation, local field enhancement, and photothermal heating have been identified as three important plasmonic effects, all of which are directly relevant to plasmonic-based photocatalysts [52].

sec.title: Hot electrons
sec.p:
The deposited metal NPs in plasmonic photocatalysts exhibit a robust collective oscillation of surface electrons under light, known as LSPR, which then decays into high-energy hot electrons. Contrary to semiconductor photocatalysts, the hot electrons produced by LSPR in the case of plasmonic photocatalysts can multiply the photocatalyst rate several times with light intensity [53]. Generation of hot electrons and injection into the semiconductor either indirectly or directly. In an indirect process, the semiconductor absorbs some of the hot electrons originally generated by the plasmonic metal. A tiny fraction of the high-energy plasmonic hot electrons can overcome the energy barrier at the interface and participate in the indirect transfer process due to the quick relaxation by electron–electron scattering. Hot electron injection and electron–electron scattering processes compete with each other in indirect transfer. This is one of the factors that lead to the indirect transfer of exceptionally low efficiency of 2%. Another factor is the possibility of electron back transfer at the interface, especially at low energy barriers [54, 55]. In the direct process, the strong interaction of the metal with the tightly coupled semiconductors creates a sufficient number of vacant hybridized orbitals that can directly induce plasmon dephasing and generate hot electrons in the vacant hybridized orbitals. The advantages of the direct electron transfer method offer high transfer productivity with less energy loss. The significant energy loss in indirect transfer arises from the injection of hot electrons across the heterojunction surface, and from the scattering of electrons and phonons in the electronic state before the transfer [56, 57]. During the direct injection process, Landau damping is used to generate hot electrons in the hybridized orbitals directly on the direct electron transfer path to prevent energy loss [58]. The indirect and direct transfer of hot electrons in the metal to a semiconductor is shown in Fig. 1a, b.Figure 1
Plasmonic hot electron transfer routes a indirect and b direct transfer in metal to a semiconductor. Adapted with permission from [58]

The shape of plasmonic metal NPs has a significant impact on hot electron production and injection processes. The results of theoretical simulations show that the rate of hot electron injection is much higher for the metal NPs compared to their spherical counterparts. When the aspect ratio of the metal NPs remains constant, the rate of hot electron injection into the semiconductor increases with increasing aspect ratio and decreases with increasing volume [59]. The photocatalytic degradation process with the plasmonic hot electron on the surface of the semiconductor degrades the pollutants in the following way. First, the plasmons are excited by the incident light, then the plasmonic energy travels from the metal to the semiconductors by injecting hot electrons that cause or enhance charge separation in the semiconductors. Second, the oxygen adsorbed on the surface of the semiconductors can accept electrons and form the superoxide radical (·O2–), while hydroxyl can fill the holes and form the hydroxyl radical (·OH). Normally, the ·O2– and ·OH are active species that degrade pollutants. In some cases, the active species that directly degrade pollutants are the e−–h+ [60]. Liu et al. constructed a Z-scheme Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst with an LSPR effect using the hydrothermal technique. The theoretical calculations and characterized techniques show that the light-generated e−–h+ of the Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst are efficiently separated and transferred via the dual-channel carrier transfer pathway using continuous hot electron injection and Z-scheme heterostructure. When irradiated with visible light, the Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst is excellent for the degradation of tetracycline (TC) and reached 87.9% in 60 min. The best photocatalytic efficiency of the Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst is owing to the dual-channel transfer of charge carriers and the injection of hot electrons by the LSPR. A successful broadband photocatalyst is made possible by the two pathways working together to speed the transfer of photoinduced charge carriers [61]. Jiang et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Au NPs/KCa2Nb3O10 nanosheets 0D/2D (Au/KCNO) photocatalysts using a precipitation-calcination method. These photocatalysts use Au NPs as photosensitizers to trap visible light and also contribute to charge separation, which enhances the photocatalytic efficiency in visible light. The Au/KCNO photocatalyst significantly degraded TC by the optimized plasmonic Au/KCNO heterojunction photocatalyst. The photocatalytic performance of a 2% Au/KCNO photocatalyst is 3.9 times better than that of bare KCNO. In Au/KCNO photocatalyst, the Au NPs in the heterojunction system serves two functions: First, they serve as photosensitizers to allow the heterojunction to harvest visible light; second, they serve as electron relays in heterojunctions to further improve charge separation and boost photocatalytic activity in visible light. Importantly, KCNO nanosheets can also significantly enhance photocatalytic efficiency by reducing the distance hot electrons must travel to reach the semiconductor/electrolyte interface after being generated by Au NPs. A possible mechanism of the plasmonic heterojunction Au/KCNO photocatalyst for the removal of TC is shown in Fig. 2 [62].Figure 2
Schematic diagram of photoinduced charge transfer and photocatalytic processes using an Au/KCNO photocatalyst to degrade TC. Adapted with permission from [62]

Ji et al. constructed a Z-scheme heterojunction W18O49/BiOBr photocatalyst using a high production rate mechanical ball milling method. Compared with pure BiOBr, the 2 wt% W18O49/BiOBr photocatalyst showed excellent stability and strong photocatalytic degradability for methyl orange (MO) and TC. A synergistic interplay between fast electron transfer via the Z-scheme, high absorption of light, and hot electron injection via plasmonic sensitization led to the best photocatalytic activity of the W18O49/BiOBr photocatalyst. The possible photodegradation mechanism is shown in Fig. 3 [63].Figure 3
Possible photodegradation mechanism of the W18O49/BiOBr photocatalyst to degrade MO and TC pollutants. Adapted with permission from [63]

sec.title: Local field effect
sec.p:
Metal NPs can produce robust local electric fields on their surface with a frequency close to their plasmon resonance frequency under light irradiation. The intensity of the electric field of local plasmonic “hot spots” is almost 1000 times larger than the incident electric field, as calculated by electromagnetic simulations using the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method [64, 65]. Thus, the rate of generation of e−–h+ pairs in these “hot spot” regions is 1000 times higher than the incident electromagnetic field. The local field enhancement of plasmonic metal NPs generates a larger amount of photoinduced charge locally in a semiconductor. Moreover, the enhancement depends on the existence of defect states in semiconductors, which are necessary to allow light absorption below the semiconductor bandgap [66]. The FDTD method is a numerical analysis technique used to simulate computational electrodynamics. The FDTD approach can naturally account for nonlinear material features and span a wide range of frequencies because it acts in the time domain [67]. The large class of grid-based methods for differential numerical modeling includes the FDTD method. Central difference approximations for the partial space and time derivatives are used to discretize the time-dependent Maxwell equations (which take the form of partial differential equations) [68, 69]. The resulting finite-difference equations are resolved in hardware or software by applying the “leapfrog” principle. To fully develop the desired transient or steady-state electromagnetic field behavior, the vector components of the electric field in a volume of space must first be solved before the vector components of the magnetic field in the same volume of space [70]. For instance, the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) and the electric field enhancement by the Ag NPs in the Ag/Ag2CO3 composite were confirmed by simulating the electric field distribution with the FDTD method. The local “hot spots” can be seen in the areas near the Ag NPs as shown in Fig. 4. Furthermore, the electric field of the Ag2CO3 surface appears to be stronger than the incident electric field in terms of intensity. This would favor the formation of e−–h+ pairs near the Ag2CO3 surface. The results show that Ag NPs can enhance the electric field and induce SPR [71].Figure 4
Local electric field distributions at Ag/Ag2CO3 interfaces were calculated by the FDTD method. Adapted with permission from [71]

Rong et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag-CoWO4/CdWO4 photocatalyst by electrospinning followed by tollens reaction. Levofloxacin (LEV) is degraded by an Ag-CoWO4/CdWO4 photocatalyst with a removal efficiency of 92.5%, demonstrating significant photocatalytic efficiency. The separation and transfer of photoinduced e−–h+ pairs are greatly promoted by the systematic construction of the p–n heterojunction with well-overlapping band potentials and internal electric field. Thus, Ag NPs also contribute to the improvement of photocatalytic efficiency by promoting the separation and transfer of charge carriers through the LSPR effect. A possible mechanism of the Ag-CoWO4/CdWO4 photocatalyst for the degradation of LEV is shown in Fig. 5 [72].Figure 5
Possible photocatalytic mechanism of Ag-CoWO4/CdWO4 photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [72]

Hayashido et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag@AgBr/mesoporous (mp)-TiO2 photocatalyst by successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction-photoreduction (SILAR-PR) methods. Under visible light irradiation, the Ag@AgBr/mp-TiO2 photocatalyst exhibits notable photocatalytic activity for the removal of 2-naphthol. Spectroscopic and photoelectrochemical studies of the Ag@AgBr/mp-TiO2 photocatalyst show the improved photocatalytic activity of Ag@AgBr/mp-TiO2 photocatalyst due to an enhancement in the local electric field near Ag clusters, which promotes the rapid generation of photocharge carriers in AgBr. Thus, AgBr functions as a photocatalyst for visible light and as an oxidation inhibitor for Ag clusters, while Ag clusters operate as amplifiers for the local electric field [73]. Sun et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme CeO2-decorated hierarchical three-dimensional tremella-shaped g-C3N4 (3DT-CN)/Ag photocatalyst by the in situ growth method. The photocatalyst CeO2@3DT-CN/Ag (Ce@15-AC) is excellent for the degradation of TC and achieved 91.7% in 40 min. When compared to 3DT-CN and 15-AC, the Ce@15-AC photocatalyst displayed the highest photocatalytic activity, showing that oxygen vacancies (OV-CeO2) greatly increased the photocatalytic degradation capacity. It is important to note that the photocatalytic performance of AC is significantly better than that of 3DT-CN, indicating the importance of LSPR effects. According to FDTD simulations and other studies, the LSPR effects of Ag NPs enhance the local electromagnetic fields in 3DT-CN and OV-CeO2. The Ag NPs have a strong enough electromagnetic field to encourage the separation and transfer of e−–h+ into 3DT-CN and OV-CeO2 and enhance their photocatalytic performance. The basic reaction mechanism of the Ce@15-AC photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 6 [74].Figure 6
Possible photodegradation mechanism of Ce@15-AC photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [74]

sec.title: Photothermal effect
sec.p: The formation of LSPR occurs when the electrons of the metal surface absorb the corresponding incident light waves. At this moment, electron–electron scattering leads to rapid heating of the excited electrons. The duration of this process is in the femtosecond range [75]. The heat then first causes the metal lattice to vibrate and heat up by electron–phonon interaction and is later released to the surrounding medium by phonon–phonon interaction. The duration of this process is in the nanosecond range [64, 76]. It is important to point out that the plasmonic photothermal effect has many advantages over conventional heating techniques: (1) the heating rate of the plasmonic photothermal effect is fast, which can improve the performance of the photocatalyst, (2) the selective heating of the plasmonic metal NPs maintains the action of the catalysts and prevents the heating of the surrounding medium during the reaction, since most of the reaction takes place at the catalyst surface, which saves energy, and (3) by adjusting various properties of the plasmonic metal NPs, the heating conditions and the performance of the catalyst can be controlled [77–79]. According to an Arrhenius dependence of the reaction rate, the energy transfer from the metal NPs to the semiconductor surface can lead to additional chemical changes due to the plasmon-induced heat [80]. Thus, the temperature of the metal NPs increases with the energy of the LSPR [81]. It was observed that the major difference between the process driven by conventional heating and the photocatalytic performance triggered through the photothermal effect in metal NPs is the energy source. In addition, the photothermal effect provides a rapid, effective, and targeted heating mechanism for the active site where a photocatalytic reaction takes place [82, 83]. The performance of photocatalytic systems is significantly influenced by the photothermal effect. Some research suggests that the photothermal effect may contribute to the enhancement of photocatalytic activity [84, 85]. However, pollutant degradation can be successfully accelerated by the high-temperature surface of the photocatalyst [86]. Studies have shown that the photothermal effect of photocatalysts can be enhanced by LSPR of metal NPs [82, 87].

Guo et al. prepared a flower-shaped polyhedral α-Fe2O3/defective MoS2/Ag photocatalyst by two-step hydrothermal and photodeposition methods for organic pollutants degradation. The photocatalyst exhibits excellent photocatalytic performance. Three possible reasons for this exceptional catalytic performance are as follows: (1) the α-Fe2O3 polyhedron collapsed in association with the layered accumulation of MoS2 sheets, which contains many active sites at the edge and a large specific surface area to produce the hollow flower-shaped structure, (2) the synergistic interactions of oxygen doping, the SPR effect, and the construction of the heterojunction facilitated the separation and transfer of charge carriers, which in turn supported the charge carrier conversion and the photocatalytic reaction, and (3) the photocatalysts enhanced light absorption and enabled the photothermal effect to support the photocatalytic performance. Figure 7a shows that the photocatalyst increased most at 172 °C and exhibited a much better photothermal effect than the original materials. The narrow band gap of α-Fe2O3 also contributed to the enhancement of the photothermal effect in the photocatalyst, as shown in Fig. 7b [88].Figure 7
a Shows infrared images of α-Fe2O3, α-Fe2O3/defective MoS2, and α-Fe2O3/defective MoS2/Ag, and b illustration of the photothermal mechanism in a semiconductor with a narrow-bandgap and a normal. Adapted with permission from [88]

Wang et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag/MoS2/TiO2 photocatalyst by a combination of solid-state chemical reduction, photodeposition, and hydrothermal methods to degrade organic pollutants. The prepared photocatalyst exhibits excellent photothermal performance and outstanding photocatalytic properties. The heterojunction structure, SPR effect of Ag NPs, and the photothermal effect in the photocatalyst are responsible for the remarkable photocatalytic performance [89]. Jiang et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag/Bi2S3/MoS2 photocatalyst by hydrothermal and photoreduction methods. The results show that the photocatalyst has the highest rate of degradation for the 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) pollutant. The reasons for the excellent photocatalytic performance are the unique heterojunction structure, the SPR effect of Ag NPs, and the additional photothermal effect in the photocatalyst [90].

sec.title: Constructed plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts
sec.p: The performance of the photocatalyst can be considerably improved by coating metal NPs on the surface of the heterojunction photocatalyst to create a plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalyst. The plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalyst can display significant visible light absorption because its LSPR is associated with the collective oscillation of surface electrons [22, 91]. Numerous studies have shown that LSPR can improve charge separation and light absorption, which enhances photocatalytic efficiency [92, 93]. In addition, LSPR in plasmonic NPs was recently found to enable efficient light harvesting in the visible and near-infrared regions [94], hot electron generation [95], local field enhancement [96], and photothermal heating effects [97]. In combination with heterojunction photocatalysts, plasmonic metal NPs open up the possibility of using different concepts to overcome deficiencies in photocatalysts. According to the mechanisms of charge separation of various plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, heterojunctions can be typically divided into five categories: Type-I, -II -III p–n junction, Schottky junction, Z-scheme, and S-scheme. In the following, each category of heterojunctions with plasmonic metal NPs is described in detail.

sec.title: Type-I, -II -III
sec.p:
The final plasmonic heterojunctions are divided into three different types (Fig. 8) based on the energy levels of the two semiconductors: straddling gap (Type-I), staggered gap (Type-II), and broken gap (Type-III). In the plasmonic type-I heterojunctions, the conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) of semiconductor A are lower and higher, respectively, than the matching bands of semiconductor B (Fig. 8a). The photogenerated electrons in the metal NPs generated by LSPR can be transported to the CB of semiconductor A, and then, the electrons and holes of semiconductor A can transfer to the CB of semiconductor B under light irradiation. However, the plasmonic type-I heterojunctions are not able to spatially separate charge carriers, which allows the generation of e−–h+ pairs in a related semiconductor, but also their rapid recombination. Moreover, the photocatalyst reactions take place in a plasmonic type-I heterojunction with low redox potential, which reduces the performance of the photocatalyst under light irradiation [98, 99]. In the plasmonic type-II heterojunction, the matching bands of semiconductor B are lower than the CB and VB of semiconductor A, as shown in Fig. 8b. Therefore, the photogenerated electrons in the metal NPs generated by LSPR can be transported to the CB of semiconductor A, and then the electrons of semiconductor A can transfer to the CB of semiconductor B, while the photogenerated holes migrate from semiconductor B to semiconductor A under light irradiation, resulting in excellent separation of charge carriers. This separation prevents rapid recombination of the charges generated by the light. A semiconductor with a suitable band position serves as a scavenger for these charges, which can react separately from each other [100, 101]. The plasmonic type-III heterojunction has a similar structure to the plasmonic type-II heterojunction (Fig. 8c), but there is no overlap of band gaps. Therefore, the plasmonic type-III heterojunctions are inappropriate to improve the separation of e−–h+ pairs because they cannot accomplish the e−–h+ separation and transfer between semiconductors [102, 103]. In short, the plasmonic type-II heterojunctions are the best system among the aforementioned traditional heterojunctions and can be used to improve photocatalytic activity because their structure is excellent for the separation of e−–h+ pairs.Figure 8
Schematic diagram of plasmonic heterojunctions: a type-I, b type-II, and c type-III

Recently, Huang et al. constructed a plasmonic type-II heterojunction urchin-like CeO2/ZnO@Au photocatalyst by hydrothermal, chemical precipitation, and photoreduction methods. By forming a heterojunction type-II with the SPR effect, the photocatalyst exhibits high photosensitivity and effectively separates photoinduced charge carriers. The limited photon penetration depth caused by light irradiation enables the Au NPs to absorb the incident light sufficiently and activate the plasmon resonance phenomenon near the surface. Landau damping excites the electrons to the SPR state (above the Fermi level) of the Au NPs, where they then generate hot electrons at the surface. Thus, the CeO2/ZnO@Au photocatalyst shows higher photocatalytic stability and performance for the degradation of Rhodamine B (RhB), 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), and naproxen (NPX). The mechanism of photoinduced charge carrier migration in the CeO2/ZnO@Au photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 9 [104].Figure 9
Possible mechanism of photoinduced charge carrier migration in the CeO2/ZnO@Au photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [104]

Heidari et al. constructed a plasmonic type-II heterojunction Ag/Bi2Sn2O7-C3N4 (Ag/BSO-BCN) photocatalyst by hybridization and sono-photodeposition methods. The Ag/BSO-BCN photocatalyst showed remarkable photocatalytic performance for TC degradation under simulated sunlight. This remarkable photocatalytic performance of Ag/BSO-BCN photocatalyst may be due to some factors: First, the separation of photoexcited e−–h+ could be enhanced by the type-II heterojunction formation between BSO and BCN semiconductors. Second, the addition of Ag NPs to the BSO-BCN composite produces an SPR that increases the amount of e−–h+ generation and light absorption in the Ag/BSO-BCN photocatalyst. The photocatalytic mechanism of the plasmonic type-II heterojunction Ag/BSO-BCN photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 10 [101].Figure 10
Mechanism of the plasmonic type-II heterojunction Ag/BSO-BCN photocatalyst for TC degradation. Adapted with permission from [101]

sec.title: p–n junction
sec.p:
A p–n junction consists of p-type and n-type semiconductors and can considerably boost the redox efficacy of the photocatalyst by preventing the recombination of the photogenerated charge carriers [105, 106]. In a plasmonic p–n junction, p-type semiconductor electrons generated by light are transferred into the n-type semiconductor, while at the same time n-type semiconductor holes generated by light are transferred into the p-type semiconductor under light irradiation. Moreover, the position of the Fermi level of metal NPs is larger than that of the p-type; therefore, the photoinduced electrons generated by LSPR in the metal NPs can be easily transferred to the p-type CB, and subsequently, the p-type electrons can migrate to the n-type CB [107]. Therefore, the idea of a p–n junction was developed, which can increase photocatalytic efficiency by stimulating the transfer of e−–h+, as shown in Fig. 11 [98]. The p-type and n-type semiconductors could be stimulated to produce e−–h+ pairs with energies that are equivalent to or higher than their bandgap values when exposed to light. The photogenerated e−–h+ pairs move to CB and VB, respectively [108–110]. Remarkably, the separation of e−–h+ in a p–n junction photocatalyst is also thermally conceivable, since the CB and VB of the p-type semiconductor are frequently larger than that of the n-type semiconductor [111]. Thus, band alignment and internal electric field interact to increase e−–h+ separation efficiency more rapidly in plasmonic p–n junction photocatalysts compared to plasmonic type-II photocatalysts [112–114].Figure 11
Schematic representation of plasmonic p–n junction

In a recent study, Wan et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Au@PbS-CdS photocatalyst by a sequential partial cation exchange process. The PbS and CdS semiconductor domains can each individually collect hot carriers generated by the excitation of plasmonic Au nanorods, as shown by photovoltage microscopy under NIR light. This leads to a longer lifetime of the charge-separating state in a unique p–n junction around Au nanorods and improved performance of the Au@PbS-CdS photocatalyst [115]. Li et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag/α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst by solvothermal and photodeposition methods. The photocatalytic performance of Ag/α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst was investigated to degrade MO under visible light irradiation. The results exhibited that the loading of plasmonic Ag NPs in the α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 composite has significantly enhanced the photocatalytic efficiency of the α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 composite. This is mainly because of the internal static electric field created at the p–n heterojunction interface of α-Bi2O3 and Bi2O2CO3 semiconductors, which leads to higher electron conductivity from Ag NPs and improved photocatalyst performance. The possible mechanism for the photodegradation of MO by Ag/α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 12 [34]. Li et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag/Ag2S/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst by in situ growth and photoreduction methods. The photocatalyst has the best photocatalytic efficiency for the degradation of LEV and TC pollutants. The enhancement of the photocatalytic efficiency of the photocatalyst is owing to (1) the creation of a p–n heterojunction in the Ag2S and Bi2MoO6 effectively promoting separation and transfer of charge carrier through the internal electric field and (2) the plasmonic Ag NPs greatly enhance the visible light harvesting ability and generate numerous hot electrons through the LSPR effect [116].Figure 12
A possible mechanism for photodegradation of MO by Ag/α-Bi2O3/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst [34]

sec.title: Schottky junction
sec.p:
Plasmonic metal NPs are placed on the surface of the semiconductor to improve efficiency through a Schottky junction [117]. The Schottky barrier is formed when photogenerated electrons of the metal migrate into the semiconductor due to the non-uniform Fermi energy [118]. The creation of a potential barrier is the result of the electron flow continuing until it reaches equilibrium with the metal NPs. To trap the electrons from the semiconductor, this barrier can act as an electron sink. Recombination of these electrons is successfully avoided because the electrons can no longer flow back to the semiconductor [118]. According to the prediction of the above theory, photoexcited e−–h+ can be efficiently separated in a plasmonic Schottky junction by transferring electrons from the CB of semiconductor A to the CB of semiconductor B. Later, the migration of these electrons to the plasmonic metal NPs occurs by forming a Schottky barrier to prevent recombination (Fig. 13) [26, 118]. Using plasmonic metal NPs to build the Schottky junction leads to unexpected results of LSPR in these materials upon irradiation [119]. As plasmonic materials, the metal NPs improve the absorption of visible light and produce hot electrons by the LSPR. This creates a robust local electric field that supports photocatalyst reactions by greatly increasing the absorption of UV and visible light in broadband and narrowband photocatalysts, respectively [120]. In short, the Schottky barrier created by the metal NPs and semiconductors makes it easier for the separation and transfer of charge carriers. Under irradiation, the metal NPs in LSPR release hot photons that extend the photoreaction to the visible or infrared regions in the photocatalysts. The Schottky barrier and LSPR combination show excellent photocatalytic activity through Schottky contacts [121].Figure 13
Schematic illustration of the charge carrier transfer in a plasmonic Schottky junction

Recently, Kavinkumar et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag/Bi2WO6/TiO2 photocatalyst by hydrothermal and chemical reduction methods. In this study, the photoexcited e−–h+ can be effectively separated by transferring electrons from TiO2 to ECB of Bi2WO6 when TiO2 and Bi2WO6 are in contact. Later, these electrons are transferred to the plasmonic Ag NPs by creating a Schottky barrier to prevent recombination. Thus, the formation of a ternary junction can efficiently increase the electron lifetime and reduce the rate of recombination for better photocatalytic efficiency. However, the Ag/Bi2WO6/TiO2 photocatalyst showed the best photocatalytic performance in removing RhB. The photocatalytic mechanism of the Ag/Bi2WO6/TiO2 photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 14 [122].Figure 14
Photocatalytic mechanism of the Ag/Bi2WO6/TiO2 photocatalyst for RhB degradation. Adapted with permission from [122]

sec.title: Z-scheme
sec.p:
In 2006, the idea of a plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalyst was first introduced by conjugating TiO2 and CdS with Au as an electron conductor. A solid electron conductor serves as a bridge for the transfer of charge carriers in a plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalyst. In the Z-scheme, photocatalyst I (PC I) and photocatalyst II (PC II) generate electrons in their CB and holes in their VB, when exposed to light, as shown in Fig. 15. The electron mediator promotes the fusion of electrons in CB of PC II and holes in VB of PC I while retaining the e−–h+ with high redox capabilities in the two semiconductors [123]. In plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalyst systems, a suitable electron conductor must be used to significantly increase the stability of the photocatalyst and the efficiency of charge carrier transfer [124]. Plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalysts have been prepared using various metal NPs because metal NPs are good electron mediators [125, 126]. It is widely known that solid conductors perform far better in solution than ionic redox conductors because they can prevent back reactions and facilitate photocatalyst recovery [127]. Additionally, the solid conductor property of the plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalysts enables rapid transfer of charge carriers and allows operation in both liquid and gas phases [128, 129]. The development of plasmonic Z-scheme photocatalyst systems is expected to improve stability and enhance their photocatalytic activity [130].Figure 15
Schematic representation of the plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction

The plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunctions provide new insight into improving the photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts by utilizing the useless e−–h+ and retaining the strong redox potential in the system. Recently, Ni et al. fabricated a hierarchical structure of flower-shaped BiOBr/Ag /ultrathin g-C3N4 (FBBov/Ag/UCN) photocatalyst by the electrostatic assembly method for the degradation of oxytetracycline (OTC). In this study, the type-II heterojunction was converted to a plasmonic Z-scheme by the addition of Ag NPs, which improved the photothermal properties of the photocatalyst. The photocarrier separation efficiency, plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction, hierarchical spatial structure, and photothermal properties were significantly improved by plasmonic Ag NPs in the photocatalyst, which increased the photocatalytic efficiency of the FBBov/Ag/UCN photocatalyst to degrade OTC [131]. Guy et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme MoS2/Ag/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst by hydrothermal and photoreduction methods. It was found that the modification of MoS2 with a small amount of Ag/Ag3VO4 significantly increased the photocatalytic efficiency in the degradation of RhB. The increased photocatalytic efficiency could be due to the development of a plasmonic Z-scheme for electron transfer. The Ag NPs act as shuttle mediators in the composite, facilitating transport and separating the photocarriers while enhancing the visible light absorption of MoS2/Ag/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst through the action of SPR [132]. Xie et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme Ag2MoO4/Ag/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst through the deposition–precipitation method. In this study, the excellent efficiency of the photocatalyst was achieved for RhB degradation under visible light. In the photocatalyst, the Ag2MoO4/Ag3VO4 composite immediately transforms into Ag2MoO4/Ag/Ag3VO4 due to the photosensitization of Ag3VO4. These Ag NPs induce the SPR and serve as a Z-scheme charge transfer bridge that enhances the efficiency of photocatalytic degradation by improving separation and preventing charge carrier recombination. The photocatalytic mechanism of the plasmonic Z-scheme Ag2MoO4/Ag/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 16 [133].Figure 16
Proposed photocatalytic mechanism of Ag2MoO4/Ag/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [133]

sec.title: S-scheme
sec.p:
S-scheme photocatalysts are divided into oxidation photocatalysts (OP) and reduction photocatalysts (RP) according to their staggered band structure, as shown in Fig. 17 [134]. In OP, the photogenerated electrons are useless, but the photogenerated holes are useful. In RP, the photogenerated electrons are useful, but the photogenerated holes are useless and are eliminated by sacrificial substances [135]. The plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction consists of OP and PR with staggered bands similar in structure to the plasmonic type-II heterojunction but with a different charge transfer mechanism. A plasmonic type-II heterojunction has a low redox potential because photogenerated e−–h+ accumulates at CB and VB from OP and PR, respectively. The plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction exhibits a high redox potential because the efficient photogenerated e−–h+ is held in CB and VB of RP and OP, respectively, while the inefficient photogenerated charge carriers recombine. Moreover, plasmonic metal NPs in the S-scheme exhibit an SPR effect. This effect not only increases the absorption capacity for visible light but also generates an intense local electric field that facilitates charge separation [136–138]. The charge transfer path in the S-scheme macroscopically looks like a “step” (from the low to the high CB), which fits the name given to it.Figure 17
The charge transfer path in plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction

Dai et al. constructed a plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction Au/g-C3N4/BiOI photocatalyst by calcining a mixture of flower-like BiOI and Au/g-C3N4 nanosheets. This Au/g-C3N4/BiOI photocatalyst showed excellent photocatalytic performance to degrade bisphenol (BP) with high cycling stability under visible light irradiation. The good charge separation efficiency, light absorption of LSPR by the Au coating, and the development of S-scheme heterojunctions that maintain robust photocatalytic oxidation and reduction activity are all factors that contributed to the excellent photocatalytic performance [139]. Mu et al. constructed a plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction Au/g-C3N4/Cu2O photocatalyst using an in situ chemistry technique for the removal of OTC. The OTC elimination showed the excellent photocatalytic performance of the photocatalyst. The excellent charge separation efficiency with the best light absorption capacity caused by the LSPR of Au NPs and the creation of an S-scheme heterojunction that retains robust photocatalytic reduction and oxidation ability all contribute to satisfactory photocatalytic performance [140]. Mei et al. constructed a plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction Ag SPR-promoted porous g-C3N4 (Pg-C3N4)/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst by a chemical deposition method. The ability of the photocatalyst to remove methylene blue (MB) was investigated and excellent photocatalyst efficiency of the Pg-C3N4/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst was obtained upon irradiation with visible light. The study shows that the photocatalytic efficiency of the Pg-C3N4/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst is enhanced by the formation of S-scheme heterojunctions in Ag3VO4 and Pg-C3N4. Moreover, the porous Pg-C3N4 structure and the SPR effect of Ag NPs enhance the local electric field effect, which serves to speed up the charge separation and inhibit the charge recombination, all of which increase the photocatalytic efficiency. The possible charge transfer of Pg-C3N4/Ag3VO4 photocatalysts is shown in Fig. 18 [141].Figure 18
The possible charge transfer of Pg-C3N4/Ag3VO4 photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [141]

sec.title: Plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts degrade organic pollutants
Degradation of organic pollutants
sec.p: The most important challenge of the twenty-first century is the fight against ever-increasing environmental pollution. Today, the world is under a cancerous grip of environmental pollution in one form or another, out of which organic pollutants in wastewater are the biggest problem [5]. Due to their high toxicity, high accumulation, and complex degradation, organic pollutants have become one of the most important topics in environmental science. Previous ecological studies have shown that organic pollutants have been present in wastewater for a very long time. Not only are they difficult to eliminate, but they also migrate quickly and can spread throughout the earth [142, 143]. It should be emphasized that organic pollutants can accumulate in humans, animals and plants and enter the food chain. They can also damage the immune system and reproductive organs, cause cancer, birth defects, and trigger allergies [144]. According to recent studies [116, 145, 146], plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are effective in the removal and mineralization of organic pollutants. The studies of the photocatalytic elimination of various organic pollutants by plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are detailed below.

sec.title: Degradation of Dye pollutants
sec.p:
Dye pollutants discharged into industrial wastewater usually attract a lot of attention because of their high toxicity. The disposal of these materials has caused major pollution in many countries around the world [147, 148]. However, more than 0.7 million tons of dyes are released annually from paper, dyeing, printing, textile and other industries and more than 15% of these dyes end up in wastewater [40]. Thus, a significant amount of colored wastewater from these industries is discharged into the natural environment. Their presence in the hydrosphere poses a serious threat to both humans and aquatic life [149]. Dyes can be used to change the color properties of various products in different industries such as textiles and chemical and rubber industries. They are generally defined as ionized and aromatic organic compounds that can combine with surfaces to impart color [150, 151]. Dye molecules are composed of auxochromes and chromophores, which are the two key components [152]. Wastewater-containing dye is a serious environmental pollutant that has adverse effects on human health. These potentially carcinogenic toxic dyes accidentally released into the water have caused catastrophic water pollution that is much beyond the capacity of nature to clean itself. The sources and pathways of the various dye pollutants in the water system are shown in Fig. 19 [153].Figure 19
The sources and pathways of various dye pollutants in water systems. Adapted with permission from [153]

Consequently, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are very effective in treating dye pollutants; however, it should be emphasized that it is critical to developing plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts suitable for large-scale applications. Recently, Peng et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI photocatalyst by oxidation polymerization and co-precipitation methods. The preparation process of the Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 20a. The optimum Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI0.10 prepared with a mass ratio of 0.10 PANI/MoO4 showed excellent photocatalytic activity of 91.8% MO degradation in 105 min after visible light irradiation (Fig. 20b). The increased photocatalytic activity of the Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI photocatalyst was caused by the p–n heterojunction and the LSPR effect of Ag NPs, which absorbed more visible light to generate hot electrons. In addition, scavenger analysis revealed that the main active species are ·O2–, ·OH and h+, which are also responsible for the removal of MO. The possible mechanism of Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI photocatalyst for the removal of MO is shown in Fig. 20c [154].Figure 20
a The fabrication process of Ag–Ag2MoO4/PAN photocatalyst, b photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared photocatalyst for the removal of MO, and c possible photocatalytic mechanism of the Ag–Ag2MoO4/PANI photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [154]

Amiri et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction Bi2WO6/Ag3PO4-Ag photocatalyst by in situ precipitation and hydrothermal methods. The photocatalytic performance of the Bi2WO6/Ag3PO4-Ag photocatalyst was studied for the degradation of malachite green (MG) and auramine-O (AO) dyes. Compared with pure Bi2WO6 and Ag3PO4, the results show that the Bi2WO6/Ag3PO4-Ag photocatalyst exhibits better photocatalytic degradation efficiency with rates of 86.90% and 82.04% for the dyes MG and AO, respectively. The excellent photocatalytic activity was caused by an increase in the diffusion rate of e−–h+ and the reduction in the recombination of e−–h+ pairs through the Z-scheme heterojunction. In addition, the synergistic interaction of Ag NPs in the Bi2WO6/Ag3PO4 composite also contributed to the enhancement of photostability and photocatalytic performance toward dye degradation through the separation of e−–h+ pairs [155]. Jiao et al. prepared a plasmonic heterojunction Ag/AgCl/Ag2MoO4 photocatalyst by sequential precipitation and photoreduction methods. When irradiated with visible light, the Ag/AgCl/Ag2MoO4 photocatalyst degrades the organic pollutants RhB and MB more effectively than pure Ag2MoO4 and Ag/AgCl. The photocatalytic activity initially increases and later decreases as the content of Ag/AgCl content in the photocatalyst increases. After 90 min, 99.9% of the RhB dye is degraded. Figure 21a shows that S4 is a more efficient degradant material than AgCl/Ag2MoO4. In addition, the degradation of the MB dye was also investigated under visible light irradiation. The degradation efficiency of S4 reached 98.3% after 90 min, as shown in Fig. 21b. In experiments on radical trapping, it was identified that photogenerated e−–h+ are the important species, while ·OH play a secondary role in photocatalysts [156]. Loka et al. prepared a thin-film plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction Ag/Cu2O/WO3 photocatalyst by a sputter deposition method to degrade MB dye. Compared to pure monoclinic WO3 films, the Ag/Cu2O/WO3 photocatalyst shows a 3.75 times higher photocatalytic efficiency for the removal of MB. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the Ag/Cu2O/WO3 photocatalyst is owing to the efficient separation of photogenerated e−–h+ by the Z-scheme heterostructure (Cu2O/WO3) in combination with LSPR of Ag [157].Figure 21
a The photocatalytic performance of Ag/AgCl/Ag2MoO4 photocatalyst for the removal RhB, and b MB. Adapted with permission from [156]

Tian et al. prepared a series of hollow mesoporous SiO2/BiOCl/PANI/Pd (HBPP) photocatalysts by hydrothermal method for the removal of MO dye. Figure 22a depicts the photocatalytic degradation of MO by HBPP photocatalysts with various Pd %wt under visible light irradiation. The photocatalytic performance of all HBPP photocatalysts is higher than that of SiO2/BiOCl/PANI (HBP). On the other hand, the photocatalytic performance of HBPP increases with Pd content up to the optimal value and then decreases with a further increase in Pd content. This is because the Pd NPs are bound to the BiOCl and show the photoexcitation of LSPR. Additionally, the semiconductors BiOCl and PANI have the potential to interact and create interfaces that could significantly improve the separation of the photogenerated e−–h+ pairs and Pd NPs with LSPR absorption bands have the potential to significantly accelerate the production of the photoexcited e−–h+ pairs in the photocatalyst. As a result, the HBPP photocatalyst shows excellent photocatalytic degradation performance under visible light irradiation. The possible mechanism of the HBPP photocatalyst for the removal of MO dye is shown in Fig. 22b [158].Figure 22
a The photocatalytic degradation of MO by HBPP photocatalyst with different Pd %wt and b photocatalytic degradation mechanism of MO by HBPP photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [158]

Dai et al. prepared a plasmonic heterojunction g-C3N4/Ag2WO4/Ag photocatalyst by depositing Ag2WO4 on g-C3N4 followed by sunlight reduction of Ag2WO4 to Ag2WO4/Ag (Fig. 23a). Under LED light irradiation, the g-C3N4/Ag2WO4/Ag photocatalyst showed noticeably improved photocatalytic efficiency. Figure 23b shows that the use of 40wt% g-C3N4 in the photocatalyst resulted in the highest 90% degradation efficiency of 40% g-C3N4/Ag2WO4/Ag photocatalyst after 80 min. When the energy of the LED is larger than the band gap of the g-C3N4 material, the electrons in the VB of g-C3N4 are pushed to the CB leaving holes in the VB. The Ag NPs can emit e−–h+ pairs and absorb visible light simultaneously owing to the SPR effect. Here, Ag NPs are used as a plasmonic hotspot to generate high-energy charge carriers; thus, the photocatalytic efficiency is enhanced when electrons are transferred from the plasmonic activation of Ag NPs to the CB of Ag2WO4 and g-C3N4 [159].Figure 23
a The fabrication process of the plasmonic heterojunction g-C3N4/Ag2WO4/Ag photocatalyst, and b photocatalytic degradation of MB by g-C3N4/Ag2WO4/Ag photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [159]

Lei et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag/Ag2S/BaTiO3 photocatalyst by hydrothermal and photoreduction methods for the degradation of MO dye. The Ag/Ag2S/BaTiO3 photocatalyst achieves a high MO degradation rate of up to 90% after 30 min. The breakthrough demonstration of an Ag/Ag2S/BaTiO3 photocatalyst utilizing the exciton-plasmon interaction and SPR effect has significantly improved the efficiency of the photocatalyst. The piezoelectric effect mainly depends on the regulation of piezoelectric potential to separate e−–h+ pairs and change the band structure to improve the photocatalytic performance for the removal of MO [100]. Chen et al. prepared a plasmonic heterojunction Ag@AgCl/ZnSn(OH)6 (Ag@AgCl/ZSH) photocatalyst by chemical precipitation and photoreduction methods for the removal of RhB and crystal violet (CV) dyes. The Ag@AgCl/ZSH photocatalyst exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity in the photodegradation of RhB (99.86%) and CV (98.56%) under visible light irradiation. The significantly improved photocatalytic efficiency of Ag@AgCl/ZSH photocatalyst is due to the excellent SPR absorption of Ag NPs and rapid electron transfer in the photocatalytic system, resulting in lower recombination rates of the photoinduced e−–h+ pairs [160]. The details of photocatalytic degradation of various dye pollutants using plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are shown in Table 1.Table 1

sec.title: Degradation of pesticide pollutants
sec.p: Pesticides are chemicals sprayed on agricultural land, public land such as parks and gardens, and other areas to eliminate harmful organisms. Both ecosystems and humans are severely affected by pesticides in water resources. These chemicals are considered mutagenic because they contain elements that can alter DNA. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), one million people worldwide suffer from acute poisoning as a result of exposure to pesticides. Statistics show that between 0.4 and 1.9% of people die each year as a result of pesticides [164, 165]. Pesticides may be the cause of 70% of these deaths. In addition, continuous exposure to lower doses of pesticides has been linked to several syndromes in the medium and long term, including numerous tumors and neurological abnormalities [166]. Therefore, it is important to degrade persistent organic pesticides appropriately. Several methods or techniques used to control pesticides in nature include photo-Fenton, photolysis, photoelectrocatalysis, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, etc. Recently, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts have attracted much attention due to their better feasibility, excellent stability, and higher degradation rate [167, 168].

Joubani et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction Fe3O4-COOH@zinc-based metal–organic framework (ZIF-8)/Ag/Ag3PO4 photocatalyst by chemical precipitation, hydrothermal and solvothermal methods. An organophosphorus insecticide (diazinon) was degraded under the influence of visible light to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of the Fe3O4-COOH@ZIF-8/Ag/Ag3PO4 photocatalyst, and 99.7% degradation was achieved. The photocatalyst showed excellent photocatalytic activity and stability when diazinon was degraded under visible light. The enhanced photocatalytic activity and stability of this Fe3O4-COOH@ZIF-8/Ag/Ag3PO4 photocatalyst may be due to the synergistic interactions between the SPR of Ag NPs and the successive energy transfer through the Z-scheme mechanism, which enables the efficient separation of e−–h+ pairs [169]. Kumari et al. prepared a plasmonic heterojunction Pd/ZnO/CuO (PZn8Cu) photocatalyst by a single-step deposition method. The photodegradation activity of photocatalysts with different Pd contents was investigated using triclopyr (TCP) under UV light irradiation. As shown in Fig. 24a, the TCP was almost completely degraded in 60 min. The Zn8Cu composite coated with 2% Pd exhibited the highest photodegradation efficiency. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the PZn8Cu photocatalyst was significantly increased by coating the metal NPs in Zn8Cu. The combination of the excited semiconductor metal oxide with the SPR metal Pd enhanced the photocatalytic efficiency under UV light, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of Pd and the binary Zn8Cu composite. The degradation mechanism of TCP by PZn8Cu photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 24b [170].Figure 24
a Photodegradation of TCP pesticide and b degradation mechanism of TCP pesticide by PZn8Cu photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [170]

Mkhalid et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag/Ag2O-TiO2 photocatalyst by a sol–gel method for imazapyr herbicide degradation. Under visible light irradiation, imazapyr was completely degraded within 180 min at an optimum loading of 1.5 wt% Ag/Ag2O in the Ag/Ag2O-TiO2 photocatalyst. The photocatalytic performance of the Ag/Ag2O-TiO2 photocatalyst is effectively enhanced by the low recombination rates of the photoinduced e−–h+ pairs originating from the p–n heterojunction between Ag2O and the mesoporous TiO2 matrix, and by the presence of Ag in the Ag2O particles, which facilitates the transfer of electrons in the p–n heterojunction [171].

sec.title: Degradation of phenol pollutants
sec.p: Phenol is the most common organic pollutant in wastewater from various industries such as petrochemical, coal mining, and petroleum refineries which are responsible for the release of phenol pollutants into the receiving environment [172]. Phenol pollutants are increasing in the marine environment due to chemical spills. Phenol pollutants are also difficult to biodegrade. Therefore, they remain in wastewater systems at very high concentrations [173]. Phenol-containing wastewater very often seeps into the ground and contaminates adjacent rivers, lakes, water reservoirs, and even agricultural land [174]. Phenol pollutants and their metabolites are carcinogenic and mutagenic in living cells. Due to their carcinogenic and acutely toxic properties, these pollutants cause significant hazards to human health and environmental damage [172, 175].

Among the various strategies for the degradation of toxic and hazardous phenolic pollutants, a plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalyst is the most promising method because it offers numerous advantages such as environmental friendliness, economy, and practicality. In addition, this photocatalyst is a potential method for the complete mineralization of phenolic pollutants into CO2 and H2O or harmless end products [176, 177]. Nayak et al. constructed a plasmonic heterojunction Ag@Ag3PO4/g-C3N4/NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) photocatalyst by combining electrostatic self-assembly and an in situ photoreduction methods for the degradation of phenol. The highest photocatalytic rate of phenol is 90% in 2 h. The photocatalytic performance of the Ag@Ag3PO4/g-C3N4/NiFe LDH photocatalyst is significantly enhanced through the construction of quasi-type-II p–n/n–n dual heterojunctions. Moreover, the enhanced activity of the as-prepared photocatalyst is mainly due to the excellent SPR absorption of Ag NPs and oxygen vacancies as Ov-type defects in NiFe LDH, which may effectively enhance the threshold for charge separation [176]. Yuan et al. prepared a plasmonic S-scheme heterojunction Bi-Bi7O9I3/Ag–AgI photocatalyst by oil melting and solid-state reduction methods. According to the experimental results, the heterostructure and SPR effect work together to efficiently enhance the separation of e−–h+. The photocatalysts also showed excellent photothermal performance and a strong SPR effect of Ag NPs. However, the Bi-Bi7O9I3/Ag–AgI photocatalyst achieved nearly 100% phenol photodegradation performance in 80 min (Fig. 25).Figure 25
Photocatalytic degradation performance of phenol by Bi–Bi7O9I3/Ag–AgI photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [177]

The improved photocatalytic performance of the prepared Bi-Bi7O9I3/Ag–AgI photocatalyst might be due to the multichannel charge transfer arising from the unique S-scheme heterojunction structure in the photocatalyst. Besides, the numerous oxygen vacancies and metal element dopants inducing the SPR effect can produce thermal electrons and enhance the amount of efficient photogenerated electrons. They also provide a special technique for hot electron injection, which is also the reason for their improved photocatalytic performance [177]. Gao et al. prepared a plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst by a simple two-step procedure Fig. 26a). The g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst was investigated for the removal of phenol under visible light, and the results showed that the photocatalyst exhibited the most effective photocatalytic performance which was about 1.4 and 8.8 times higher than that of g-C3N4 and LaFeO3, respectively (Fig. 26b). According to radical scavenging studies, ·O2–, ·OH and h+ are the active species in the photocatalytic degradation reaction. Other studies have shown that the close contact between g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 and the vectorial transfer of charge through the local electric field of Ag NPs can enhance the photogenerated e−–h+ separation in g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 to form a photocatalytic Z-scheme mechanism that improves their photocatalytic performance. The photodegradation mechanism of the g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 26c [178]. Toe et al. prepared a plasmonic Z-scheme Si@Au NPs on CuBi2O4/BiVO4 photocatalyst by photoreduction and impregnation methods. The photocatalytic performance of CuBi2O4/BiVO4 photocatalyst is improved by the presence of plasmonic Si@Au materials as they act as a solid-state intermediate to drive the Z-scheme charge carrier mechanism. As shown by the high phenol degradation of up to 95% within 3 h, this leads to an efficient photocatalyst for the degradation of pollutants by visible light. It suggests the development of strong reactive oxygen species such as ·OH, which rapidly decomposes phenol into shorter and simpler organic molecules [126].Figure 26
a The fabrication process of the g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst, b photodegradation of phenol by g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst and c photocatalytic mechanism of phenol by g-C3N4/Ag/LaFeO3 photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [178]

sec.title: Degradation of antibiotic pollutants
sec.p:
Antibiotics are extremely important drugs and are widely used to treat and prevent infectious diseases in both animals and humans. Among the various classes, quinolone, β-lactam, TC, macrolide, sulfonamide, and penicillin are the most usually prescribed antibiotics [179]. Recently, antibiotics have been widely used for both therapeutic and nontherapeutic purposes in aquaculture, animal husbandry, and crop production. Moreover, antibiotics are also used to treat infectious diseases such as COVID -19, chemotherapy, transplantation, and surgical treatments. However, antibiotic residues have inevitably entered the aquatic environment due to misuse, overuse, and delayed metabolism, resulting in resistant sources of contamination [180, 181]. Low- and middle-income countries including China and India, saw the largest increases in consumption, 103%, and 79%, respectively. At the current rate of consumption, antibiotic use is expected to increase another 15% by 2030. Rapid population growth, urbanization, and the emergence of infectious diseases are the main drivers of this sharp increase in global consumption [182]. In addition, the number of antibiotics used in livestock (cows, poultry, and pigs) is estimated to be about 118,940 tons in 2013 and is projected to increase by 52% in 2030, with China being the largest user after the USA [183]. TC was the most commonly used class of antibiotics for livestock in both the European Union and the USA at about 33% and 32%, respectively [184, 185]. The three main threats posed by antibiotics to the environment are as follows: (1) the structural sizes of biological populations and the modalities of nutrient transfer are affected, disrupting the ecological balance of the food chain, (2) organisms in the environment contain high levels of antibiotics, endangering human health along the food chain and (3) the growth and spread of microbes are caused by the widespread development of antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Studies have shown that 68 different forms of antibiotic pollutants are present in surface water and more antibiotic pollutants have also been discovered in drinking water [186]. The sources and pathways of antibiotic pollutants in the environment are shown in Fig. 27.Figure 27
The sources and pathways of antibiotic pollutants in the environment. Adapted with permission from [187]

Antibiotic contamination is currently a serious global environmental problem. However, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts have recently received much attention due to their ability to degrade or mineralize a variety of antibiotics [116, 140]. Thus, Wang et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction Ag/Bi5FeTi3O15/ultrathin g-C3N4 (BFTO/Ag/UCN) photocatalyst by ultrasonic and photoreduction methods for the degradation TC. The BFTO/Ag/UCN photocatalyst had the highest degradation efficiency (86%) in removing TC at a mass ratio of 2% Ag in the photocatalyst, as shown in Fig. 28. According to the results, the final photocatalytic degradation efficiency is significantly affected by both the ultrathin g-C3N4 and the Ag content. In short, the prepared BFTO/Ag/UCN photocatalyst significantly enhances the charge carrier separation efficiency and improves the antibiotic degradation performance [188].Figure 28
Photocatalytic degradation of TC by BFTO/Ag/UCN photocatalyst with different wt% of Ag. Adapted with permission from [188]

Heidari et al. constructed a plasmonic type-II heterojunction Ag/Bi2Sn2O7-C3N4 (Ag/BSO-BCN) photocatalyst by hybridization and sono-photodeposition methods. The photocatalyst showed excellent photocatalytic efficiency (89.1%) for the degradation of TC. Several factors contribute to this photocatalytic efficiency. First, the formation of a type-II heterojunction between BSO and BCN semiconductors can enhance the separation of photoexcited e−–h+. Second, the addition of Ag NPs to the BSO-BCN composite and the resulting generation of SPR can broaden the light absorption spectrum, enhance the separation and transfer of excited carriers and inhibit the recombination of e−–h+ [101]. Li et al. constructed a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag/Ag2S/Bi2MoO6 (AAS/BMO) photocatalyst by in situ deposition and photoreduction methods for the degradation of LEV and TC (Fig. 29a). As shown in Fig. 29b, c, the synergistic effect of Ag NPs and p–n heterojunction Ag2S/Bi2MoO6 increased the photocatalytic degradation efficiency over LEV and TC to 87% and 93%, respectively. These remarkable photocatalytic degradation activities can be attributed to the LSPR, which can enhance the separation and transfer efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers and generate a large number of hot electrons in the photocatalyst. It is also noted that ·O2–, ·OH and h+ are essential for the photocatalytic degradation of LEV and TC [116].Figure 29
a Schematic diagram of the preparation process of Ag/Ag2S/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst, and b, c photocatalytic degradation of LEV and TC by Ag/Ag2S/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst. Adapted with permission from [116]

Zhao et al. constructed a plasmonic Z-scheme heterojunction Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst by hydrothermal method for the removal of TC (Fig. 30a). Among the as-prepared photocatalysts with different Ag content, the 5Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst has the most effective photocatalytic performance, as shown in Fig. 30b. The photocatalytic efficiency of 5Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst for the removal of TC reached 94.9% in 160 min. The enhanced photocatalytic efficiency of the Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst is due to the higher LSPR absorption in the visible light range and the efficient separation and transfer of charge carriers in a photocatalyst. Moreover, the development of a built-in electric field contributes to the efficient separation of the photogenerated e−–h+ through the Z-scheme-based charge transfer mechanism. In the Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst, the semiconductors C3N4 and SnS2 have the potential to interact with each other and create interfaces that could significantly enhance the separation of the photogenerated e−–h+ pairs and Ag NPs with LSPR absorption bands have the potential to significantly accelerate the production of the photoexcited e−–h+ pairs, all properties responsible for enhancing the photocatalytic efficiency [189]. Liu et al. constructed a Z-scheme Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst with LSPR effect by hydrothermal method for TC degradation. The TC removal efficiency over the photocatalyst reaches 87.9% after 60 min under visible light irradiation. The outstanding photocatalytic ability of the Zn2In2S5/W18O49 photocatalyst was generated by the hot electron injection process excited by the LSPR effect and the dual-channel carrier transfer pathway consisting of a Z-scheme heterostructure. The two pathways synergistically accelerate the transfer of photoinduced charge carriers, resulting in a successful photocatalyst with a broad spectrum [61]. Li et al. prepared a plasmonic p–n heterojunction Ag/p-Ag6Si2O7/n-Bi2MoO6 (AASO/BMO) photocatalyst by a controlled precipitation photoreduction method for the degradation of ciprofloxacin (CIP) and TC. The degradation efficiency of CIP by AASO/BMO-3 photocatalyst is 92.8% in 120 min (Fig. 31a). Similarly, the degradation efficiency of TC by AASO/BMO-3 photocatalyst is 89.8% in 160 min under visible light irradiation (Fig. 31b). These remarkable photocatalytic degradation activities can be attributed to the LSPR, which can enhance the separation and transfer efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers in the AASO/BMO photocatalyst. It is also found that ·O2–, ·OH and h+ are essential for the photocatalytic degradation of CIP and TC. A possible photocatalytic mechanism of AASO/BMO photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 31c [190]. Ni et al. prepared a plasmonic heterojunction BiOBr/Ag/ultrathin g-C3N4 (FBBov/Ag/UCN) photocatalyst by the electrostatic assembly method for the degradation of OTC. The FBBov/Ag/UCN photocatalyst showed remarkable photocatalytic efficiency (91.7%) for the degradation of OTC. It is suggested that the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the photocatalyst is due to the heterojunction structure, the SPR effect of Ag NPs, and the photothermal effect in the photocatalyst [131]. The details of photocatalytic degradation of various antibiotics by plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are shown in Table 2.Figure 30
a The preparation process of the Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst, and b photocatalytic efficiency of Ag-C3N4/SnS2 photocatalyst for the removal of TC. Adapted with permission from [189]Figure 31
