sec.title: Mechanism of degradation
sec.p: In recent decades, heterojunction photocatalysts have attracted much attention and proved to be a promising green and environmentally friendly method to remove organic pollutants in wastewater because they have unique properties, such as easy production, low cost, chemical stability, and non-toxicity, and heterojunction photocatalysts can convert pollutants into harmless compounds with the help of abundant sunlight [10–12, 191]. However, heterojunction photocatalysts have some drawbacks that limit their practical application such as rapid charge carriers recombination and limited absorption of visible light, which reduces the photocatalytic efficiency [16, 42]. Thus, the photocatalytic efficiency of the heterojunction photocatalyst can be greatly improved by coating the photocatalyst surface with metal NPs as plasmonic materials, which are called plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts [196]. The plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts contribute to the significantly enhanced separation of photoexcited charge carriers and absorption of light owing to its LSPR associated with the collective oscillation of surface electrons [21, 91]. Various modification methods have been proposed for the preparation of the plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalyst to incorporate plasmonic metal NPs as a co-catalyst in the heterojunction photocatalyst [197, 198]. The modification of heterojunction photocatalysts with plasmonic metal NPs is an efficient way because the LSPR in plasmonic materials can increase the light absorption and the best separation of charge carriers, which can greatly improve the photocatalytic activity of the material in the elimination of organic pollutants [199, 200].

Recently, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts have attracted enormous attention for organic pollutants degradation [61, 201, 202]. This is due to the remarkable properties of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts such as (1) effective separation and transfer of photogenerated e−–h+, (2) improvement of stability, and (3) enhancement of light absorption of the photocatalyst [92, 203]. Moreover, LSPR in plasmonic metal NPs is beneficial to the performance of photocatalytic processes in many ways. For instance, it helps to generate hot charge carriers [33], enhance the local electric field [34], and improve photothermal heating [35, 36]. Consequently, all these unique properties of plasmonic metal NPs deposited on the surfaces of heterojunction photocatalysts can efficiently enhance the photocatalytic performance in removing organic pollutants.

The fundamental mechanism associated with photocatalytic degradation is as follows [204, 205]. The overall process consists of the following steps: (Step: I) When the energy of the light is greater than the bandgap of the photocatalyst, the excited e−–h+ generates a high reduction or oxidation capacity. Then, the photoinduced e−–h+ is separated and migrates to the photocatalyst surface; (Step: II) during the migration process, some e−–h+ recombine and generate heat; (Step: III) the reduction pathway is initiated, in which O2 is reduced to ·O2– by electron migration on the photocatalyst surface; (Step: IV) in contrast, the oxidation pathway begins where ·OH is produced by the oxidation of H2O through the migration of holes on the photocatalyst surface. Thus, these photocatalytic active species (·O2–· or ·OH) play a crucial role in the elimination of organic pollutants [206]. All these processes influence the final rate and effectiveness of pollutant removal by photocatalysts within the photocatalytic strategy.

In general, the efficiency of heterojunction photocatalysts is low due to problems such as fast recombination of photogenerated e−–h+ pairs, limited absorption of light, and lack of active sites. To inhibit the recombination of e−–h+ pairs and retain their reducing and oxidizing abilities, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts are an effective strategy to design optimal photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation [43]. The construction of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts is an ideal method to prevent the recombination of e−–h+ because there are some effects such as hot electrons, strong local field, and photothermal effect, which can make the separation of charge carriers more efficient by facilitating the opposite motions of photoinduced e−–h+, resulting in a remarkable improvement of photocatalytic performance [213, 214]. The general mechanism of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation is shown in Fig. 32.Figure 32
Schematic representation of the mechanism of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation

sec.title: Conclusions and challenges
sec.p:
In this review paper, we presented the basic concept of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, explained the mechanism of the plasmonic effect in heterojunction photocatalysts to enhance photocatalytic activity, and reviewed recent advances in plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the elimination of organic pollutants. The plasmonic effect in heterojunction photocatalysts is widely recognized to improve the performance of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation, although the research study is still in the evaluation stage. To advance the development of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts and broaden the range of their applications, researchers must draw inspiration from these flourishing experimental studies as well as theoretical predictions. The following aspects should be the focus of future research in this area.
Current photocatalytic materials have several limitations, including small active surfaces, large bandgap, high cost, etc. Affordable and innovative materials are needed for the development of heterojunction photocatalysts with plasmonic metal nanoparticles (NPs) that effectively degrade organic pollutants. For the successful development of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, a material must meet several criteria, such as high light absorption performance, excellent e−–h+ separation ability, suitable bandgap, and high photostability for long-term applications.
For plasmonic metal NPs to respond to visible light and exhibit charge migration capability, their shape and contact with heterojunctions are critical. Although some studies have attempted to control the morphology of plasmonic metal NPs, studies on in situ fabrication of plasmonic metal NPs in controlled morphology with specific active parts of the heterojunction surface are still lacking. In the application of photocatalytic degradation, this has a remarkable influence on the reaction effect of the heterojunction surface. The interfacial contact and dispersion of the metal NPs on the heterojunction surface need to be studied in detail to precisely control the shape of the metal NPs.
The addition of plasmonic metal NPs to heterojunction photocatalysts can improve their photocatalytic performance to some extent due to the plasmonic effect. This is because both the charge separation ratio and visible light absorption are enhanced by local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR). The extent to which the LSPR effect in the plasmonic heterojunctions contributes quantitatively to their strong photocatalytic activity also needs to be thoroughly investigated. This would demonstrate the utility of the LSPR effect in photocatalysts and promote the development of advanced heterojunctions photocatalysts with plasmonic metal NPs for organic pollutants degradation.
Much more attention should be paid to theoretical calculations and modeling techniques. To better understand the kinetics of charge migration and the mechanism of plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts, further theoretical calculations are urgently needed to clarify the actual picture of photocatalytic processes in these materials.

In summary, plasmonic-based heterojunction photocatalysts for the elimination of organic pollutants from wastewater are likely to be a hot topic in the near future. Nevertheless, it is crucial to fully understand the pathway of the degradation process to design or use the appropriate amount of metal NPs in heterojunction photocatalysts for better photocatalytic performance. For some samples, the simultaneous photodegradation of organic pollutants involves a complicated mechanism that requires a catalyst with excellent e−–h+ separation capabilities. Moreover, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are an extremely valuable technique in photocatalytic research to analyze the structural properties and performance of materials. Therefore, the experimental results combined with comprehensive characterization methods and theoretical simulations will greatly enhance our understanding of environmental photocatalysts and accelerate the use of plasmonic-based heterogeneous photocatalysts in the removal of organic pollutants. In addition, the design and optimization of operating factors for photocatalytic systems based on wastewater characteristics need to be studied in more detail. Since most studies to date have been conducted in laboratories, there is still a large gap before the technology can be applied on a large scale. Therefore, further studies on the design, modeling, and operation of pilot-scale photocatalytic reactors are needed.
